questions.question: In patients presenting with non-healing surgical incisions, what is the most commonunderlying cause?
questions.explanation: All the factors listed impair wound healing, but local infection is the most common underlyingcause of non-healing surgical incisions.To reduce the chances of infection, the surgeon should make every effort to remove all devitalizedtissue and leave a clean wound for closure.Factors affecting wound healing:• Site of the wound• Structures involvedMechanism of wounding (crushing, incision, avulsion)• Contamination. Loss of tissue• Local factors (vascularity, previous irradiation, pressure)•Systemic factors (malnutrition, anemia, steroids, AIDS, smoking)

questions.question: A child with a grazed knee comes to your clinic for first aid. He has a history of nephroticsyndrome and is on oral prednisolone therapy. Which stage of wound healing would be mostaffected by his medication?
questions.explanation: While all of the given options are inhibited by steroids, the major effect of steroids is to inhibit theinitial inflammatory phase of wound healing (angiogenesis, neutrophil and macrophagemigration, and fibroblast proliferation) and the release of lysosomal enzymes.The stronger the anti-inflammatory effect of the steroid compound used, the greater the inhibitoryeffect on wound healing. Steroids used after the first 3 to 4 days post-injury do not affect woundhealing as severely as when they are used in the immediate postoperative period.In addition to inhibiting collagen synthesis, steroids also inhibit epithelialization and contractionand contribute to increased rates of wound infection, regardless of the time of administration.Steroid delayed healing of cutaneous wounds can be stimulated to epithelialize by topicalapplication of vitamin A.

questions.question: Which of the following findings in a long-standing ulcer would indicate malignanttransformation?
questions.explanation: Everted edge around a chronic wound is a sign of malignant transformation.The majority of wounds that have not healed in 3 months are considered chronic and are prone tomalignant changes. Malignant wounds are differentiated clinically from non-malignant wounds bythe presence of overturned edges. Biopsy of the wound edges should be performed to rule outmalignancy.Malignant transformation can occur in any long-standing wound. The image shows a Marjolin'sulcer with everted edges. It is squamous cell carcinoma that develops on a long-standing burn.1096

questions.question: A 21-year-old man came to the casualty 12 hours after sustaining a laceration on his leg froma trekking accident. On closer examination, other than dirt, you do not notice any pus orsigns of infection. What is the most appropriate management?

options.A: Closure after granulation tissue has formed
options.B: Delayed closure 2 days after removal of devitalised tissue
options.C: Primary closure after adequate wound toileting and debridement
options.D: Wound debridement, topical antibiotics and dressing

questions.explanation: Contaminated wounds older than 6 hours should be managed with delayed primary closure.The wound is cleaned, debrided, and left open for a few days. This allows soft tissues to drain andalso ensures no infection is present before surgical closure can be done.Wound closure is categorized into primary, secondary, or tertiary:Primary closure is done for clean wounds with minimal tissue loss that are amenable toapproximation of wound edges. Healing occurs by primary intention. Primary closure is ideallyperformed within 6 to 8 hrs of trauma, but wounds in vascular areas (e.g. face) may be delayed toup to 24 hours after trauma.Secondary closure allows healing by secondary intention. The wound is left open to heal largely bythe formation of granulation tissue and contraction. These wounds often have significant tissueloss precluding tension-free approximation of edges, with devitalized edges. Wound dressings arechanged daily to aid in the formation of granulation tissue and subsequent contraction.Tertiary closure, also known as delayed primary closure, results in a combination of healing byprimary and secondary intention. The wound is thoroughly irrigated, debrided, and left open for 2to 5 days before surgical closure. It is used for wounds that are grossly contaminated withoutsignificant tissue loss.

questions.question: Stage the bedsore in the following image:1084
questions.explanation: The given image shows complete skin loss that involves muscles and shows exposed boneindicating a stage 4 pressure sore.Pressure sores are skin or soft tissue injuries that occur due to prolonged pressure over specificareas of the body. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.1097The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are the ischium, greater trochanter,sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, specialpressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen thepressure on the area.Ulcers of stages 1 and 2 often do not require operative measures. They are managed with regularwound cleaning and dressing with a good antibiotic cover.Stage 3 and 4 ulcers are adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is used topromote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that havemuscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

questions.question: An elderly paraplegic patient admitted to a nursing home, developed an ulcer on her glutealregion. All of the following are true regarding the management of this patient except:1085

options.A: Diet and nutritional support should aim to establish a positive nitrogen balance
options.B: Following debridement, exposure of the wound is recommended
options.C: Tensor fascia lata flap with an intact nerve supply may be used for covering the defect
options.D: Frequent change in position and air mattresses can help in preventing further sores

questions.explanation: The given image is that of a grade 3 bedsore. A grade 3 pressure sore requires dressing followingdebridement.Preoperative management involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure(VAC) to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure. Alginates, foams, hydrocolloids, hydrogelsare other options that are available.The aim of surgery is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flapsthat include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included(e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh).Nutritional optimization with high caloric and protein diet should be done to establish a positivenitrogen balance. Frequent changes in position and air mattresses can also help in preventingfurther sores.

questions.question: A meshed skin graft was used to cover a defect and vacuum-assisted closure of the transplantwas done. What is the pressure generated within the dressing?
questions.explanation: The pressure used in vacuum-assisted closure for wound healing is -125 mmHg.1098Applying negative pressure appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulationtissue in chronic wounds and ulcers.It acts by decreasing edema, by removing interstitial fluid, and as a result, helps in decreasingbacterial counts and cell proliferation increases.

questions.question: A man who had undergone an exploratory laparotomy 6 months ago came for a follow-upvisit. Which of the following statements about healed incision is false?

options.A: Disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines
options.B: Strength of the scar is in their weave rather than in their amount
options.C: By the first week it is held by sutures and a weak type 3 collagen matrix
options.D: Tensile strength is about 60-80% of normal skin by 3 months

questions.explanation: During the first week, a surgical wound has minimal inherent strength because the dermal edgesare held together solely by a hemostatic plug and sutures.During the second postoperative week, fibroblasts proliferate rapidly and begin to produce type Icollagen in addition to type III. The strength of the wound is still limited to less than 10% of itsfinal strength. By week 6, the concentration of strong collagen fibers begins to resemble that ofintact skin.As the collagen matures and becomes denser, the scar becomes almost acellular as the fibroblastsand blood vessels reduce. The disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines withtheir strength being in their weave rather than in their amount.Most of these changes occur over the first three months but a scar will continue to mature for 1 to2 years. Tensile strength will continue to increase but would not be expected to exceed 60-80% ofthat of normal skin.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?

options.A: The extent does not cross the wound margins
options.B: Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
options.C: Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
options.D: A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.explanation: Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factor leading to increased proliferationof fibrous tissue.A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the originalincision or wound (option A) and rarely regresses on its own. It is more common indarker-pigmented ethnicities.It can arise from surgery, burns, skin inflammation, infections, ear piercing, and evenspontaneously. questions.question: A patient has been treated for the lesion shown in the picture below for the past 12 monthsbut there has been no response to treatment. What is the next line of treatment for thispatient?1088
questions.explanation: Surgical excision in combination with adjuvant therapy is advised to patients with refractorykeloids.The adjuvant therapy usually includes radiation. The risk of malignancy attributable to keloidradiation therapy is minimalTreatment of keloids :• First-line treatments include silicones in combination with pressure therapy and intralesionalcorticosteroid injections.1101• Intralesional 5-fluorouracil, bleomycin, and verapamil should be used in accordance withestablished treatment protocols.• Refractory cases after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical excision incombination with adjuvant therapy.•Excision alone results in a high recurrence rate of 50% to 100% and enlargement of the keloid.• Immediate postoperative electron beam irradiation or brachytherapy with iridium-192 reducesrecurrence rates. The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid radiation therapy is minimal.• An additional new invasive treatment modality is internal cryotherapy, in which a metal rod isintroduced into the keloid and the subsequent extreme cooling leads to tissue necrosis.

questions.question: Which of the following techniques will you use to reduce suture marks and scars?
questions.explanation: Fine sutures (6/0 or smaller) placed close to the wound margins tend to cause lessscarring. Subcuticular suturing avoids suture marks on either side of the wound or incision.Suture marks can be minimized using monofilament sutures that are removed early (3-5 days).Wounds can be strengthened post-suture removal by the use of sticky strips.

questions.question: A 68-year-old diabetic presented with a foot ulcer that he first noticed 1 month ago. The edgesare irregular with sloped margins. The ulcer does not bleed to touch. Peripheral pulses arefelt and an arterial doppler does not indicate a compromised blood flow. Which growth factorhas been formulated and approved for treatment?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diabetic foot ulcer. At present, PDGF (platelet-derivedgrowth factor)-BB is currently approved by the FDA for the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers.Application of recombinant human PDGF-BB in a gel suspension to these wounds increases theincidence of total healing and decreases healing time.
